IS AI COMING FOR YOUR JOB? 

I get asked this all the time -- isn’t AI going to kill software jobs? And I get why people ask. It’s a logical question on the surface. If AI can write code, why do you need engineers? If an LLM can build your front-end, generate test cases, and spin up infrastructure, doesn’t that mean the talent market just imploded?

But that’s a misunderstanding of how business -- and capital -- actually works.

Because in the real world, productivity doesn’t reduce headcount. It reallocates resources. When a CEO sees that one engineer is now delivering what used to take a team of ten, they don’t think, great, I’ll cut my workforce by 90%. They think, finally, I can build everything we couldn’t justify before. That’s not fantasy -- that’s history. That’s what happens every time the cost of creation drops and the return on talent explodes. 

Go back to the Industrial Revolution. People thought the steam engine would destroy labor -- and in some ways, it did. The work changed. Manual weavers were displaced. But what came next was an explosion of industry, logistics, cities, and trade. New roles appeared that no one could’ve imagined -- engineers, factory managers, supply chain operators. The economy didn’t shrink. It scaled.

Same with the assembly line. When $F introduced it, critics said it would de-skill workers and eliminate craftsmanship. What actually happened? Car prices dropped, wages went up, and an entire middle class emerged -- built on a foundation of mass-scale productivity.

Or take the rise of personal computing. In the '80s, fears swirled that office jobs would disappear. Spreadsheets would kill accounting. Word processors would kill secretaries. But PCs didn’t destroy work. They amplified it. Every business function -- finance, sales, HR -- suddenly operated at higher velocity. That wasn’t the end of the workforce. It was the start of knowledge work as we know it.

Fast forward to cloud computing. It was supposed to make IT departments obsolete. Instead, it made startups possible. The idea that a company could go from idea to global scale without owning a single server changed everything -- and unlocked the explosion of SaaS, e-commerce, and mobile.

AI fits into this lineage. It reduces friction. It collapses time. It makes individual contributors exponentially more powerful. And when you unlock that kind of leverage, the rational response isn’t to cut -- it’s to scale.

Yes, some forms of labor will vanish. Entry-level tasks, boilerplate scripting, manual QA -- they’ll get compressed, automated, abstracted away. But that doesn’t mean less work. It means DIFFERENT work. Higher-leverage work. Work that requires judgment, creativity, and the ability to orchestrate AI systems like instruments, not just push buttons on them. The best engineers won’t just be coders -- they’ll be conductors. The same goes for designers, marketers, ops people, analysts. The future isn’t about doing less. It’s about multiplying what one person can do.

And here’s the part everyone misses: when output per head rises, companies don’t shrink. They scale. Because now the economics make sense. Now, a startup doesn’t need a hundred people to go from prototype to product. A five-person team with access to the right models can build, test, launch, and scale faster than a fifty-person org ever could. That’s not a thought experiment -- it’s already happening. The companies that win in this era won’t be the ones with the biggest headcount. They’ll be the ones that learned to make every head count more.

So when new grads worry that there’s no place for them, the answer isn’t to retreat. It’s to adapt. Learn the tools. Use the models. Stop optimizing your resume for a role that GPT can do, and start figuring out how to build the things GPT makes possible. This is the most asymmetric playing field we’ve ever had. The barriers to building have collapsed. A billion-dollar company can now be started by a handful of people and a few fine-tuned prompts. That’s unprecedented. And it flips the risk-reward equation for an entire generation.

AI won’t kill ambition. It just rewrites what it takes to compete.

Message to Michelle Bowman and Chris Waller, both current FOMC members.

If they want to be Fed Chairman, they better go to war with the FOMC in July for rate cut.

3 weeks ago, Trump was calling on the Fed cut the funds rate 100 bps

Last week he started saying the Fed should cut 200 to 300 bps.

Today he says the funds rate should be 1% (350 bps cut).

Right on track to get him to demand negative interest rates somewhere after July 4th.

This is a "tracker." That means it sums all the data that feeds into GDP and gives its run rate.

My often-used metaphor is like taking your marathon time at mile 10 and projecting the finishing time. However, you still have 16 more miles to go. You go speed up, or slow down.

This tracker only incorporates data for April and some of May, as well as revisions to date. We still have more May data, all of June (the first June numbers are due next week with ISM and payrolls), and revisions ahead of us.

So, a lot more data is coming. That said, 2.9% is a decent run rate. This covers April and May when markets were down and everyone was freaking out. June was a time when everyone relaxed, and the stock market rebounded to new highs.

Suppose Trump picks Fed Governor Chris Waller, a current member of the FOMC. In that case, he expects Waller to start lobbying for rate cuts immediately – essentially holding the FOMC hostage, twisting arms, and doing whatever is necessary to get the Fed to cut rates now. 

If Waller cannot do this, then he’s not up for the job according to Trump’s standards. Is Waller ready for this Hobbesian choice? Is the Fed prepared for a potential onslaught from within starting very soon?

If Trump picks an outsider, like Warsh or Hassett, they have far less power until they actually become Fed chair in May 2026. The Fed has time to prepare.

-The Fund’s strategy is subject to all potential losses if the Underlying ETF’s share decline, which may not be offset but the income received by the Fund,
